title: If a video game was designed the same way that the Christian God designed the universe, then it would be totally stupid.

author: spinner198
text:
As a Christian gamer I have no idea what you are talking about here. Not every video game is the same genre. You have tons of games with easy difficulty, where you just relax and don't have to worry about 'losing', and you have tons of games that are extremely difficult that players find an immense satisfaction in overcoming. What games you like or don't like depends on the kind of person you are to a degree.

Or are you just referring to this life as the 'first level'? You can lose in lots of games, but you can just retry until you win. The purpose of the game isn't to judge your moral character, and the purpose of life isn't just to entertain.

author: spinner198
text:
Ah, I wasn’t prior aware of this but this sub’s rules say to use the SEP for definitions by default. So we’ll just use that. The SEP provides a LOT of discussion and theory on what ‘evidence’ means, but the general trend among all of them is that evidence is something which justifies belief.

Of course, then we are left to wonder how we can quantify whether something ‘justifies’ belief. There isn’t an objective method of doing so. The closest thing to a ‘justification’ of belief would simply be the presence of belief itself. That is, if somebody believes X, then whatever they personally think *justifies* that belief *is* evidence. So basically, evidence is reason for belief.

“Reason for belief”. That is the definition of evidence we shall work with, until you bother to provide an alternative definition.

In that case, the universe is sufficient reason to believe in a creator, just as a painting is evidence of an artist. Because I see the universe, I have reason to believe it has a creator. Our human understanding sees complex things, and we conclude that they are a result of design. A painting. A skyscraper. Stonehenge. Anthills. Even such simple things as two rocks on top of one another. These things imply designers, and indeed they *are* designed. In that sense, it is reasonable to extend this ides to the entire universe.

The universe is complex and works within the boundaries of rules. Thus, it is reasonable to believe it was designed that way, just like Stonehenge. In this sense, apparent design within our universe is evidence for a designer; a creator.

You could argue “Maybe it happened randomly” since random chance is the *only* alternative to design, but then you would be staring down the challenge of also demonstrating that Stonehenge was not designed but rather the result of ‘random chance’, or that the Mona Lisa was not designed but rather a result of random chance.

So there you have it. According to the definition of evidence which we are using, there is evidence for a designer/creator. Congratulations.
